awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Dynamic Regulation of Axonal Morphology by Neurofilament Transport
awd_abstract_narration:
Nerve cells extend long, thin protrusions called axons that define the wiring pattern of the nervous system. Axons allow nerve cells to communicate electrically with each other and with other cells throughout the body. Each axon contains a microscopic, internal scaffold of space-filling proteins called neurofilaments that are constantly shuttled along the axon by molecular motor proteins; these define axon shape and size. Neurofilaments accumulate during development, increasing axon diameter and allowing electrical activity to travel more quickly; excessive accumulation (as occurs in many neurodegenerative diseases) can lead to communication abnormalities and axonal degeneration. This project tests the hypothesis that the rate of neurofilament transport determines the diameter, shape and function of axons.  The work will be conducted by a seasoned interdisciplinary team of biologists and physicists, combining innovative biological imaging techniques with mathematical and computational methods to investigate these important questions. The insights gained from this research will be critical for understanding healthy brain function and could also provide important insights into the axonal problems observed in many neurodegenerative diseases. Trainees on this project from both the physical and life sciences will work in teams supervised by the principal investigators, and will expand their skills through interdisciplinary interaction, adding to the skilled research workforce at the interface of the physical and life sciences. To extend the impact of the proposed research to the K-12 level, the physicists and biologists on this project will host focused, small-group workshops that will seek to empower middle and high school teachers with ideas and tools to invigorate their instruction in the areas of cell biology and algorithmic thinking, and introducing freely available but powerful learning tools that they can apply in their classrooms.

The function of nervous systems is dependent on the propagation of action potentials along axons at a velocity that is specific to their physiological function. This velocity is dependent on axon size and shape. A principal determinant of axon size and shape in vertebrates are space-filling cytoskeletal polymers called neurofilaments. Neurofilaments are also cargoes of axonal transport that move along microtubule tracks. Thus, neurofilaments define axonal morphology, but they are also in constant flux. The proposed research addresses this intriguing and physiologically important relationship. The central hypothesis is that the kinetics of neurofilament transport determines axonal neurofilament content, which in turn specifies axonal caliber and function. The specific goals are to determine the dynamic interplay between neurofilament transport velocity and flux in the specification of overall axon caliber, and how neurofilaments navigate local constrictions at the nodes of Ranvier. To accomplish these goals, the investigators will employ a tight integration of computational and mathematical methods with innovative live imaging of myelinated axons in peripheral nerves ex vivo from a new transgenic mouse that expresses a photoactivatable neurofilament protein in neurons.

por.por_cntn:
The brain consists of billions of neurons communicating with each other through electric signals traveling along long and slender extensions of neurons, called axons. Essential for brain function is that the signals arrive at their target at the right time which requires them to travel at the correct velocity. An important determinant of signal velocity is the cross sectional area of the axon. The main thrust of this project was to study the mechanisms by which the axon acquires its target shape

 

Neurofilaments are the most abundant space filling structures in the axon and a predictor of axon diameter. The larger the axon diameter, the larger the number of accumulated neurofilaments across the axon cross section. Neurofilaments are assembled in the cell body and transported along the axon, a phenomenon that is called axonal transport. The main goal of this project was to test the hypothesis that axon diameter is controlled by both, the flux of neurofilaments into the axon and their transported velocity. The project was a collaboration between two researchers, one a biologist at Ohio State University with expertise in neurofilaments and axonal transport, and the other a physicist at Ohio University with expertise on computational modeling.  A strength of the proposed research was the tight integration of experimental and computational approaches to explore a fundamental problem in cellular neuroscience that cannot presently be understood by experimentation alone.  

 

The research project resulted in 10 peer-reviewed articles (P. Jung and A. Brown combined) and supported the training of six graduate students, three post-docs, one undergraduate and one high school student with diverse backgrounds in the physical and life sciences.  The project has also supported a high school teacher training program in coding with free, but powerful software, that fit a school budget.

 

A key outcome of the project is that the growth of axons towards their target diameter is dominated by an increase of neurofilaments assembled in the cell body and transported along the axon at early stages of postnatal development. At later stages of development the growth of axon diameter is dominated by a slowing of neurofilament movement. These findings demonstrate the hypothesized relationship between axon diameter, neurofilament movement, and flux into the axon. Since the assembly and the transport of neurofilaments requires metabolic energy, this growth strategy minimizes the metabolic energy required for the growth of the diameter of the axon during development. 

 

Nodes of Ranvier are critical for the rapid propagation of the nerve impulses along the axon.  It has been shown previously that axons are constricted at the nodes and that these constrictions increase the velocity of nerve conduction. These constrictions, however, are an impediment for neurofilament transport which raises the question how neurofilaments navigate them without accumulating near the nodes. To sustain a stable morphology of myelinated axons, neurofilaments must accelerate in the nodes just like water in a narrowing pipe must accelerate. We found that the mechanism for this acceleration is an increased proximity of neurofilaments to the tracks along which they are transported.  This finding also demonstrates the relationship between neurofilament transport velocity and axon diameter. 

 

The main outcomes above have been obtained under the hypothesis that all neurofilaments in an axon are mobile and that they move in anterograde and retrograde directions in vivo. To address this hypothesis, a novel pulse-spread fluorescence photo-activation method has been developed. Using a transgenic mouse, a directional bias of 60% anterograde and 40% retrograde was found, establishing that neurofilaments move antero and retrogradely in mature axons in vivo. 

We have used the fluorescence photoactivation pulse-escape technique to test whether there is a stationary phase of neurofilaments that do not contribute to axonal transport.  We showed that 80% of the initially photoactivated GFP departed from an activation window within three hours and an extrapolation predicted that 99% of neurofilaments departed within 10 hours, suggesting that all neurofilaments in the axon were mobile.
